34.title: Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention
34.legal_text: When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of common intention, each is liable as if done alone.
34.punishment: Same as main offence, as per Section 35
34.nature:
Not Applicable (Rule of Evidence)
Cognizable: Depends on main offence
Bailable: Depends on main offence
Compoundable: Depends on main offence
Triable by: Court triable for main offence
34.practical_explanation: If multiple people plan and commit a crime together, every member is equally responsible for the act.
34.example: If A and B plan to rob a bank and B shoots a guard, A is also liable for the shooting due to common intention.
next_steps: Establish lack of common intention if falsely accused.
34.conclusion: Section 34 imposes joint liability for acts done with common intention.
34.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

107.title: Abetment of a thing
107.legal_text: A person abets the doing of a thing who instigates, engages in conspiracy, or intentionally aids the act.
107.punishment: Punishable under Section 109 if act is committed
107.nature:
Depends on offence abetted
Cognizable: Depends on main offence
Bailable: Depends on main offence
Compoundable: Depends on main offence
Triable by: Court triable for main offence
107.practical_explanation: Encouraging, helping, or conspiring to commit a crime makes you an abettor, which is also a crime.
107.example: A gives a knife to B knowing B intends to stab C. A is liable for abetment.
next_steps: Do not provide assistance to illegal acts.
107.conclusion: Abetment expands liability to those who help or encourage crimes.
107.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

109.title: Punishment of abetment
109.legal_text: Punishment for abetment if the act is committed in consequence and no express provision is made for its punishment.
109.nature:
Depends on offence abetted
Cognizable: Depends on main offence
Bailable: Depends on main offence
Compoundable: Depends on main offence
Triable by: Court triable for main offence
109.practical_explanation: If you help someone commit a crime and they do it, you get the same punishment as them.
109.example: A instigates B to break a window. B does it. A is punished as if A broke it.
next_steps: Prove lack of intent or participation.
109.conclusion: Ensures abettors face consequences equal to perpetrators.
109.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

120B.title: Punishment of criminal conspiracy
120B.legal_text: Punishment for being party to a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence.
120B.punishment: Same as abetment of the offence (if serious); or up to 6 months/fine
120B.nature:
Serious Offence: Cognizable / Non-bailable / Non-compoundable / Session Court
Other: Non-cognizable / Bailable / Non-compoundable / Magistrate First Class
120B.practical_explanation: Agreeing with others to commit a crime is punishable, even if the crime doesn't happen.
120B.example: Three people meet and plan a bank heiist but represent caught before doing it.
next_steps: Prove lack of agreement or participation.
Withdraw from conspiracy early and report.
120B.conclusion: Conspiracy itself is a substantive offence punishable by law.
120B.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

141.title: Unlawful assembly
141.legal_text: An assembly of five or more persons is designated an 'unlawful assembly' if the common object is criminal.
141.nature:
Definition (Punished under 143)
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
141.practical_explanation: A group of 5+ people gathering to commit a crime or disturb peace.
141.example: A mob of 10 people gathering to block a public road illegally.
141.conclusion: Defines what constitutes an illegal group gathering.
141.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

143.title: Punishment for unlawful assembly
143.legal_text: Whoever is a member of an unlawful assembly shall be punished.
143.punishment: Imprisonment up to 6 months, or fine, or both
143.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
143.practical_explanation: Penalty for being part of an illegal mob.
143.example: Simply being present in a riotous mob can get you arrested.
143.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

146.title: Rioting
146.legal_text: Whenever force or violence is used by an unlawful assembly, or by any member thereof, in prosecution of the common object.
146.nature:
Definition (Punished under 147)
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
146.practical_explanation: When an unlawful assembly turns violent.
146.example: A protest turning violent where stones are thrown.
next_steps: Consult lawyer for bail and defense.
146.conclusion: Defines violence by a group as rioting.
146.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

153A.title: Promoting enmity between different groups
153A.legal_text: Promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, etc.
153A.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
153A.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
153A.practical_explanation: Hate speech or acts that cause tension between communities.
153A.example: A speech inciting violence against a specific religious group.
next_steps: Seek anticipated bail if creating controversial content.
153A.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

166.title: Public servant disobeying law, with intent to cause injury to any person
166.legal_text: Public servant knowingly disobeying any direction of the law as to the way he is to conduct himself, intending to cause injury.
166.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
166.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
166.practical_explanation: When an official deliberately ignores the law to hurt someone.
166.example: Investigation officer intentionally ignoring evidence to hurt the accused's case.
next_steps: File a complaint with superior officers.
166.conclusion: Holds public servants accountable for malicious legal disobedience.
166.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

167.title: Public servant framing an incorrect document with intent to cause injury
167.legal_text: Public servant framing or translating a document incorrectly with intent to cause injury.
167.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
167.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
167.practical_explanation: Official faking or twisting records to harm someone.
167.example: Police officer writing a false report to implicate an innocent person.
167.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

174.title: Non-attendance in obedience to an order from public servant
174.legal_text: Intentionally omitting to attend at a certain place and time in obedience to a summons or order.
174.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 1 month, or fine up to 500 rupees, or both
174.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
174.practical_explanation: Ignoring a subpoena or court summons.
174.example: Failing to appear in court as a witness after being summoned.
174.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

177.title: Furnishing false information
177.legal_text: Legally bound to furnish information to public servant, and furnishing false information.
177.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 6 months, or fine up to 1000 rupees, or both
177.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
177.practical_explanation: Lying to an official when required to tell the truth.
177.example: giving a false address to a police officer when booked.
next_steps: Claim lack of knowledge if applicable.
177.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

186.title: Obstructing public servant in discharge of public functions
186.legal_text: Voluntarily obstructing any public servant in the discharge of his public functions.
186.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine up to 500 rupees, or both
186.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
186.practical_explanation: Stopping an official from doing their job.
186.example: Physically blocking a health inspector from entering a building.
next_steps: Do not physically engage with officials.
186.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

188.title: Disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant
188.legal_text: Disobedience to an order lawfully promulgated effectively directing likely to cause obstruction, annoyance or injury.
188.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 1 month, or fine, or both
188.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
188.practical_explanation: Ignoring official orders like Curfew or Section 144 orders.
188.example: Gathering in a group when Section 144 is imposed.
188.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

191.title: Giving false evidence
191.legal_text: Whoever being legally bound by an oath to state the truth, makes any statement which is false.
191.nature:
Defined in 191 (Punished in 193)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
191.practical_explanation: Perjury; lying under oath in court.
191.example: Witness lying about seeing the accused at the crime scene.
next_steps: Stick to the truth in court.
Correct testimony before leaving stand if mistake made.
191.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

211.title: False charge of offence made with intent to injure
211.legal_text: Instituting criminal proceedings against a person knowing that there is no just or lawful ground.
211.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both (more if offence falsely charged is serious)
211.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
211.practical_explanation: Malicious prosecution; filing false cases to harass someone.
211.example: Accusing a neighbor of theft knowing they didn't do it.

overlaps.description: False information with intent to cause public servant to use power

211.conclusion: Punishes misuse of the legal system.
211.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

217.title: Public servant disobeying direction of law with intent to save person from punishment
217.legal_text: Public servant knowingly disobeying direction of law with intent to save person from punishment or property from forfeiture.
217.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
217.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
217.practical_explanation: Official letting a criminal go or hiding their assets illegally.
217.example: Police officer destroying evidence to help a friend.
217.conclusion: Prevents corruption and favoritism in law enforcement.
217.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

295A.title: Deliberate and malicious acts, intended to outrage religious feelings
295A.legal_text: Deliberate and malicious acts, intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or religious beliefs.
295A.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
295A.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
295A.practical_explanation: Intentionally insulting religion to provoke anger.
295A.example: Posting a derogatory image of a deity online.
295A.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

302.title: Punishment for murder
302.legal_text: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
302.punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, and fine
302.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
302.practical_explanation: Intentional killing of a human being.
302.example: Pre-planned killing of a business rival.
next_steps: Do not make confessions without lawyer.
302.conclusion: The most serious offence in IPC.
302.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

304.title: Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder
304.legal_text: Whoever commits culpable homicide not amounting to murder.
304.punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 10 years and fine
304.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
304.practical_explanation: Killing someone without the high level of intent required for murder.
304.example: Hitting someone in a fight which unintentionally causes death.
304.conclusion: Punishes killing that falls short of murder.
304.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

307.title: Attempt to murder
307.legal_text: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge, and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of murder.
307.punishment: Imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine; if hurt is caused, life imprisonment
307.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
307.practical_explanation: Trying to kill someone but failing.
307.example: Shooting at someone but missing or causing minor injury.
next_steps: Surrender and seek bail (hard to get).
Prepare defense on lack of intent.
307.conclusion: Punishes the intent to kill as severely as killing in some cases.
307.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

323.title: Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt
323.legal_text: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 334, voluntarily causes hurt.
323.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine up to 1000 rupees, or both
323.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
323.example: Slapping or punching someone causing bruises.
323.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

324.title: Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means
324.legal_text: Voluntarily causing hurt by means of any instrument for shooting, stabbing, cutting, etc.
324.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
324.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
324.example: Hitting someone with an iron rod.
324.conclusion: Aggravated form of hurt due to weapon use.
324.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

325.title: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt
325.legal_text: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 335, voluntarily causes grievous hurt.
325.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine
325.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with court permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
325.practical_explanation: Causing serious injury like breaking a bone or losing an eye.
325.example: Breaking someone's arm in a fight.
next_steps: Try to compound with victim if allowed.
325.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

326.title: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means
326.legal_text: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by means of any instrument for shooting, stabbing, cutting, etc.
326.punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine
326.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
326.practical_explanation: Causing serious injury with a weapon.
next_steps: Bail is difficult; prepare strong grounds.
326.conclusion: Very serious offence, often close to attempted murder.
326.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

354.title: Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty
354.legal_text: Assault or criminal force to any woman, intending to outrage or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby outrage her modesty.
354.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
354.practical_explanation: Molestation; physical act disrespecting a woman.
354.example: Groping or pulling a woman's clothes.
354.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

354A.title: Sexual harassment and punishment for sexual harassment
354A.legal_text: Physical contact and advances involving unwelcome and explicit sexual overtures; or demand or request for sexual favors; or showing pornography; or making sexually coloured remarks.
354A.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both (for physical contact/demand); Up to 1 year for others
354A.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
354A.example: Asking for sexual favors at work.
next_steps: File complaint with internal committee (if workplace).
354A.disclaimer: This is informational content only and not legal advice.

378.title: Theft
378.legal_text: Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of the possession of any person without that person's consent, moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft.
378.nature:
Definition (Punished under 379)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
378.practical_explanation: Taking someone else's movable property without their permission dishonestly.
378.example: Pickpocketing a wallet from someone's pocket.

379.title: Punishment for theft
379.legal_text: Whoever commits theft shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
379.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
379.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Compoundable (value < 2000 or with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate

380.title: Theft in dwelling house, etc.
380.legal_text: Theft in any building, tent or vessel, which building, tent or vessel is used as a human dwelling, or used for the custody of property.
380.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
380.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
380.practical_explanation: Stealing from inside a house or building used for storage/living.
380.example: Burglar entering a home and stealing jewelry.
380.conclusion: More serious than simple theft due to violation of dwelling.

383.title: Extortion
383.legal_text: Whoever intentionally puts any person in fear of any injury to that person, or to any other, and thereby dishonestly induces the person so put in fear to deliver to any person any property.
383.nature:
Definition (Punished under 384)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
383.practical_explanation: Forcing someone to give money or property by threatening them.
383.example: Threatening to publish compromising photos unless paid money.

384.title: Punishment for extortion
384.legal_text: Whoever commits extortion shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
384.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
384.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
384.example: Blackmailing a shopkeeper for protection money.

390.title: Robbery
390.legal_text: In all robbery there is either theft or extortion. Theft is 'robbery' if, in order to the committing of the theft, or in committing the theft, or in carrying away or attempting to carry away property obtained by the theft, the offender, for that end, voluntarily causes or attempts to cause to any person death or hurt or wrongful restraint.
390.nature:
Definition (Punished under 392)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
390.practical_explanation: Theft or extortion involving immediate violence or threat of death/hurt.
390.example: Holding a knife to someone's throat to steal their watch.
390.conclusion: Robbery is an aggravated form of theft/extortion.

392.title: Punishment for robbery
392.legal_text: Whoever commits robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
392.punishment: Imprisonment up to 10 years (14 years if on highway between sunset and sunrise) and fine
392.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class

395.title: Punishment for dacoity
395.legal_text: Whoever commits dacoity shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
395.punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine
395.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
395.practical_explanation: Robbery committed by 5 or more people working together.
395.conclusion: One of the most serious property crimes.

403.title: Dishonest misappropriation of property
403.legal_text: Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use any movable property.
403.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
403.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
403.practical_explanation: Keeping found property or using someone else's property for yourself dishonestly.
403.example: Finding a gold ring and selling it instead of finding the owner.

405.title: Criminal breach of trust
405.legal_text: Whoever, being in any manner entrusted with property, dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use that property.
405.nature:
Definition (Punished under 406)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
405.practical_explanation: Betraying trust regarding money or property entrusted to you.
405.example: An employee using company funds for personal vacation.

406.title: Punishment for criminal breach of trust
406.legal_text: Whoever commits criminal breach of trust shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
406.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
406.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
406.practical_explanation: Penalty for violating trust with property.
406.example: A cashier stealing money from the till.

415.title: Cheating
415.legal_text: Whoever, by deceiving any person, fraudulently or dishonestly induces the person so deceived to deliver any property... constitutes cheating.
415.nature:
Definition (Punished under 417)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
415.practical_explanation: Deceiving someone to get them to do something or give something.
415.example: Selling a fake watch claiming it is real.

417.title: Punishment for cheating
417.legal_text: Whoever cheats shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
417.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
417.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
417.example: Lying about a product feature to make a sale.

420.title: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property
420.legal_text: Whoever cheats and thereby dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver any property to any person... shall be punished.
420.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
420.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
420.practical_explanation: Serious fraud where property is obtained by deception. The famous '420' offence.
420.example: Taking money for a job promise and disappearing.
next_steps: Prepare evidence of lack of intent.
420.conclusion: The primary section for serious fraud and con-artistry.

425.title: Mischief
425.legal_text: Whoever with intent to cause, or knowing that he is likely to cause, wrongful loss or damage to the public or to any person, causes the destruction of any property...
425.nature:
Definition (Punished under 426)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

426.title: Punishment for mischief
426.legal_text: Whoever commits mischief shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine, or with both.
426.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine, or both
426.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

441.title: Criminal trespass
441.legal_text: Whoever enters into or upon property in the possession of another with intent to commit an offence or to intimidate, insult or annoy any person in possession of such property...
441.nature:
Definition (Punished under 447)
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
441.practical_explanation: Entering someone's property without permission to cause trouble.
441.example: Entering a neighbor's garden to threaten them.

447.title: Punishment for criminal trespass
447.legal_text: Whoever commits criminal trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine, or with both.
447.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine, or both
447.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

448.title: Punishment for house-trespass
448.legal_text: Whoever commits house-trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
448.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
448.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
448.practical_explanation: Entering a house or building illegally.
448.example: Entering someone's home without invitation to argue.

463.title: Forgery
463.legal_text: Whoever makes any false documents or false electronic record or part of a document or electronic record, with intent to cause damage or injury...
463.nature:
Definition (Punished under 465)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
463.example: Signing someone else's name on a check.

464.title: Making a false document
464.legal_text: A person is said to make a false document or false electronic record...
464.practical_explanation: The act of creating the fake part of a document.
464.example: Altering a date on a contract.

465.title: Punishment for forgery
465.legal_text: Whoever commits forgery shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
465.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
465.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class

468.title: Forgery for purpose of cheating
468.legal_text: Whoever commits forgery, intending that the document or electronic record forged shall be used for the purpose of cheating.
468.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
468.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
468.practical_explanation: Forging a document specifically to cheat someone out of money/property.
468.example: Forging a property deed to sell land that isn't yours.

471.title: Using as genuine a forged document or electronic record
471.legal_text: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly uses as genuine any document or electronic record which he knows or has reason to believe to be a forged document.
471.punishment: Same as if he had forged it (Section 465 or 468)
471.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
471.practical_explanation: Using a fake document knowing it is fake.
471.example: Submitting a fake marksheet for a job application.
471.conclusion: Using a forgery is as bad as making one.

498A.title: Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty
498A.legal_text: Whoever, being the husband or the relative of the husband of a woman, subjects such woman to cruelty shall be punished.
498A.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years and fine
498A.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
498A.practical_explanation: Cruelty (physical or mental) by husband or in-laws, often related to dowry.
498A.example: Harassing a wife for not bringing enough dowry.
498A.conclusion: Specific law to protect married women from cruelty.

499.title: Defamation
499.legal_text: Whoever, by words either spoken or intended to be read... makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm... the reputation of such person.
499.nature:
Definition (Punished under 500)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
499.practical_explanation: Damaging someone's reputation via speech or writing.
499.example: Writing a false article claiming someone is a thief.

500.title: Punishment for defamation
500.legal_text: Whoever defames another shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
500.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
500.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class

503.title: Criminal intimidation
503.legal_text: Whoever threatens another with any injury to his person, reputation or property... with intent to cause alarm to that person.
503.nature:
Definition (Punished under 506)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
503.practical_explanation: Threatening someone to frighten them or make them do something.
503.example: Threatening to beat someone up if they don't withdraw a complaint.

504.title: Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace
504.legal_text: Whoever intentionally insults, and thereby gives provocation to any person, intending or knowing it to be likely that such provocation will cause him to break the public peace.
504.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
504.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
504.practical_explanation: Abusing someone firmly to provoke a fight.
504.example: Using abusive language in a public argument.

506.title: Punishment for criminal intimidation
506.legal_text: Whoever commits the offence of criminal intimidation shall be punished... If threat be to cause death or grievous hurt, etc.
506.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years (Simple); Up to 7 years (Aggravated - death threat)
506.nature:
Part 1: Non-cognizable / Bailable
Part 2 (Death threat): Cognizable / Non-bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
506.practical_explanation: Punishment for threatening someone. Severity depends on the threat (e.g. death threat is serious).

509.title: Word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman
509.legal_text: Whoever, intending to insult the modesty of any woman, utters any word, makes any sound or gesture, or exhibits any object...
509.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 3 years and fine
509.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
509.practical_explanation: Verbal or gestural harassment of a woman.
509.example: Making lewd comments or gestures at a woman.

511.title: Punishment for attempting to commit offences punishable with imprisonment for life or other imprisonment
511.legal_text: Whoever attempts to commit an offence punishable by this Code with imprisonment for life or imprisonment... and in such attempt does any act towards the commission of the offence.
511.punishment: Up to half the imprisonment term of the main offence
511.nature:
Same as the offence attempted (usually)
Cognizable / Bailable (varies)
Triable by court triable for main offence
511.practical_explanation: If you try to commit a crime but fail, you can still be punished for the attempt.
511.example: Checking a pocket to steal property but finding it empty (Attempt to theft).
511.conclusion: General provision for punishment of attempts.

279.title: Rash driving or riding on a public way
279.legal_text: Whoever drives any vehicle, or rides, on any public way in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life...
279.punishment: Imprisonment up to 6 months, or fine up to 1000 rupees, or both
279.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
next_steps: Appear in court if summons received.

304A.title: Causing death by negligence
304A.legal_text: Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide.
304A.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
304A.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
304A.practical_explanation: Accidental death caused by carelessness (e.g. road accident).

304B.title: Dowry death
304B.legal_text: Where the death of a woman is caused by any burns or bodily injury or occurs otherwise than under normal circumstances within seven years of her marriage...
304B.punishment: Imprisonment for not less than 7 years but which may extend to life
304B.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
304B.practical_explanation: Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage due to harassment for dowry.
304B.example: Bride burning or suicide due to dowry demands.

147.title: Punishment for rioting
147.legal_text: Whoever is guilty of rioting, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
147.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
147.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
147.practical_explanation: Penalty for participating in a riot.
147.example: Being part of a violent mob.

148.title: Rioting, armed with deadly weapon
148.legal_text: Whoever is guilty of rioting, being armed with a deadly weapon...
148.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
148.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
148.practical_explanation: Rioting while carrying weapons like knives, swords, or guns.

149.title: Every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object
149.legal_text: If an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common object of that assembly, every person who... is a member of the same assembly, is guilty of that offence.
149.nature:
Cognizable (if offence is)
Bailable (if offence is)
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court triable for main offence
149.practical_explanation: Vicarious liability: If one member of the mob kills someone, everyone can be charged with murder.
149.example: Being in a mob where someone shoots a police officer.
149.conclusion: Expands liability to all group members.

160.title: Punishment for committing affray
160.legal_text: Whoever commits an affray, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine, or with both.
160.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 month, or fine, or both
160.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
160.practical_explanation: Fighting in a public place disturbing peace.
160.example: Two people fighting on a street corner.

182.title: False information, with intent to cause public servant to use his lawful power to the injury of another person
182.legal_text: Whoever gives to any public servant any information which he knows or believes to be false...
182.punishment: Imprisonment up to 6 months, or fine, or both
182.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
182.practical_explanation: Misleading police or officials to harass someone.
182.example: Filing a false complaint to get police to raid a neighbor.

201.title: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender
201.legal_text: Whoever, knowing that an offence has been committed, causes any evidence... to disappear...
201.punishment: Depends on the offence (7 years, 3 years, etc.)
201.nature:
Cognizable (if offence is)
Bailable (generally)
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session or Magistrate
201.practical_explanation: Destroying evidence or lying to protect a criminal.
201.example: Cleaning bloodstains from a crime scene.
next_steps: Do not tamper with crime scenes.

212.title: Harbouring offender
212.legal_text: Whenever an offence has been committed, whoever harbours or conceals a person whom he knows or has reason to believe to be the offender.
212.punishment: Depends on offence (5 years, 3 years, etc.)
212.nature:
Cognizable (if offence is)
Bailable (generally)
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
212.practical_explanation: Hiding a criminal from the police.
212.example: Letting a fugitive stay in your house.

268.title: Public nuisance
268.legal_text: A person is guilty of a public nuisance who does any act or is guilty of an illegal omission which causes any common injury, danger or annoyance to the public...
268.nature:
Definition (Punished under 290)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
268.practical_explanation: Doing something that annoys or endangers the general public.
268.example: Blocking a public road with construction material.

269.title: Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life
269.legal_text: Whoever unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life.
269.punishment: Imprisonment up to 6 months, or fine, or both
269.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
269.practical_explanation: Carelessness that could spread a deadly disease.
269.example: Breaking quarantine while infected with COVID-19.

294.title: Obscene acts and songs
294.legal_text: Whoever, to the annoyance of others, does any obscene act in any public place, or sings, recites or utters any obscene song...
294.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine, or both
294.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
294.practical_explanation: Doing or saying dirty things in public.
294.example: Singing lewd songs near a school.

319.title: Hurt
319.legal_text: Whoever causes bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person is said to cause hurt.
319.nature:
Definition (Punished under 323)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

320.title: Grievous hurt
320.legal_text: Designates 8 kinds of hurt as grievous: Emasculation, loss of sight/hearing, loss of limb, fracture, dangerous hurt.
320.nature:
Definition (Punished under 325)
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
320.practical_explanation: Severe injuries like broken bones, permanent damage.

332.title: Voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty
332.legal_text: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt to any person being a public servant in the discharge of his duty...
332.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
332.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
332.practical_explanation: Hitting a police officer or official who is working.

339.title: Wrongful restraint
339.legal_text: Whoever voluntarily obstructs any person so as to prevent that person from proceeding in any direction in which that person has a right to proceed.
339.nature:
Definition (Punished under 341)
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
339.practical_explanation: Stopping someone from going where they want to go.
339.example: Blocking someone's path on a sidewalk.

341.title: Punishment for wrongful restraint
341.legal_text: Whoever wrongfully restrains any person shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine, or with both.
341.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 1 month, or fine, or both
341.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
341.example: Preventing a neighbor from leaving their house.

340.title: Wrongful confinement
340.legal_text: Whoever wrongfully restrains any person in such a manner as to prevent that person from proceedings beyond certain circumscribing limits.
340.nature:
Definition (Punished under 342)
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
340.practical_explanation: Locking someone in a room or space against their will.

342.title: Punishment for wrongful confinement
342.legal_text: Whoever wrongfully confines any person shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
342.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
342.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
342.example: Unlawful detention by a security guard.

351.title: Assault
351.legal_text: Whoever makes any gesture, or any preparation intending or knowing it to be likely that such gesture... will cause any person present to apprehend that he... is about to use criminal force.
351.nature:
Definition (Punished under 352)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
351.practical_explanation: Threatening gesture making someone fear immediate violence.
351.example: Raising a fist as if to hit someone.

352.title: Punishment for assault or criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation
352.legal_text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation...
352.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine, or both
352.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

353.title: Assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty
353.legal_text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person being a public servant in the execution of his duty...
353.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
353.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
353.practical_explanation: Pushing or attacking an official to stop them from working.
353.example: Shoving a police officer during a protest.

354C.title: Voyeurism
354C.legal_text: Any man who watches, or captures the image of a woman engaging in a private act in circumstances where she would usually have the expectation of not being observed.
354C.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable (1st offence), Non-bailable (2nd)
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
354C.practical_explanation: Peeping or recording women in private moments.
354C.example: Hidden camera in a changing room.

354D.title: Stalking
354D.legal_text: Any man who follows a woman and contacts, or attempts to contact such woman to foster personal interaction repeatedly despite a clear indication of disinterest; or monitors usage by a woman of the internet, email or any other form of electronic communication.
354D.punishment: First conviction: Up to 3 years; Second: Up to 5 years
354D.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable (1st offence), Non-bailable (2nd)
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
354D.practical_explanation: Following a woman or monitoring her online against her will.
354D.example: Repeatedly messaging a woman who has blocked you.

359.title: Kidnapping
359.legal_text: Kidnapping is of two kinds: kidnapping from India, and kidnapping from lawful guardianship.
359.nature:
Definition (Punished under 363)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
359.practical_explanation: Taking a minor away from parents without consent.
359.example: Taking a child from school without parent's permission.

363.title: Punishment for kidnapping
363.legal_text: Whoever kidnaps any person from India or from lawful guardianship shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
363.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
363.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class

375.title: Rape
375.legal_text: A man is said to commit 'rape' who has sexual intercourse with a woman under circumstances falling under any of the seven descriptions (against her will, without consent, etc.).
375.nature:
Definition (Punished under 376)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session

376.title: Punishment for rape
376.legal_text: Whoever commits rape shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment of not less than ten years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
376.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
376.conclusion: One of the most severe punishments in IPC.

494.title: Marrying again during lifetime of husband or wife
494.legal_text: Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries in any case in which such marriage is void by reason of its taking place during the life of such husband or wife.
494.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
494.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
494.practical_explanation: Bigamy; marrying someone else while already married.
494.example: Husband marrying a second wife without divorcing the first.

121.title: Waging, or attempting to wage war, or abetting waging of war, against the Government of India
121.legal_text: Whoever wages war against the Government of India, or attempts to wage such war, or abets the waging of such war, shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
121.punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, and fine
121.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
121.practical_explanation: Armed rebellion or war against the Indian state.
121.example: Leading an armed insurgent group against the army.
121.conclusion: The most serious offence against the state.

124A.title: Sedition
124A.legal_text: Whoever by words... brings or attempts to bring into hatred or contempt, or excites or attempts to excite disaffection towards the Government established by law in India.
124A.punishment: Imprisonment for life, to which fine may be added, or with imprisonment which may extend to three years, to which fine may be added, or with fine.
124A.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
124A.practical_explanation: Speech or acts inciting hatred against the government (Note: Supreme Court has paused this law).
124A.example: Speech urging violent overthrow of the government.

193.title: Punishment for false evidence
193.legal_text: Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding.
193.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
193.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
193.practical_explanation: Lying in court or faking evidence for a trial.

228A.title: Disclosure of identity of the victim of certain offences etc.
228A.legal_text: Whoever prints or publishes the name or any matter which may make known the identity of any person against whom an offence under section 376, 376A... is alleged or committed.
228A.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years and fine
228A.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
228A.practical_explanation: Revealing the name/photo of a rape victim.
228A.example: Newspaper publishing name of a sexual assault survivor.
228A.conclusion: Protects privacy of sexual offence victims.

230.title: Coin defined
230.legal_text: Coin is metal used for the time being as money, and stamped and issued by the authority of some State or Sovereign Power in order to be so used.

231.title: Counterfeiting coin
231.legal_text: Whoever counterfeits or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting coin.
231.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
231.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class

255.title: Counterfeiting Government stamp
255.legal_text: Whoever counterfeits, or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting, any stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue.
255.punishment: Imprisonment for life or up to 10 years and fine
255.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session

295.title: Injuring or defiling place of worship with intent to insult the religion of any class
295.legal_text: Whoever destroys, damages or defiles any place of worship, or any object held sacred by any class of persons...
295.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
295.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
295.practical_explanation: Vandalizing a temple, mosque, church, etc.
295.example: Throwing garbage into a holy shrine.

296.title: Disturbing religious assembly
296.legal_text: Whoever voluntarily causes disturbance to any assembly lawfully engaged in the performance of religious worship, or religious ceremonies.
296.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
296.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
296.practical_explanation: Disrupting a prayer meeting or religious procession.
296.example: Playing loud music intentionally to disrupt prayers.

297.title: Trespassing on burial places, etc.
297.legal_text: Whoever, with the intention of wounding the feelings of any person, or of insulting the religion of any person... commits any trespass in any place of worship or on any place of sepulchre.
297.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
297.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

298.title: Uttering, words, etc., with deliberate intent to wound the religious feelings of any person
298.legal_text: Whoever, with the deliberate intention of wounding the religious feelings of any person, utters any word or makes any sound in the hearing of that person...
298.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
298.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
298.practical_explanation: Speaking specifically to hurt someone's religious feelings.
298.example: Using slurs against someone's god to their face.

312.title: Causing miscarriage
312.legal_text: Whoever voluntarily causes a woman with child to miscarry, shall, if such miscarriage be not caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the woman, be punished.
312.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both (7 years if quick with child)
312.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
312.example: Forcing someone to have an abortion without medical necessity.

313.title: Causing miscarriage without woman's consent
313.legal_text: Whoever commits the offence defined in the last preceding section without the consent of the woman...
313.punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine
313.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
313.practical_explanation: Forcing an abortion on a woman against her will.
313.example: Husband spiking wife's drink to cause miscarriage.

330.title: Voluntarily causing hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property
330.legal_text: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt for the purpose of extorting from the sufferer or any person interested in the sufferer any confession...
330.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
330.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
330.practical_explanation: Police or anyone beating someone to get a confession.
330.example: Custodial torture to get a confession.

388.title: Extortion by threat of accusation of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, etc.
388.legal_text: Whoever commits extortion by putting any person in fear of an accusation against that person... of having committed or attempted to commit any offence punishable with death...
388.punishment: Imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine (Life if offence threatened is unnatural offence)
388.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
388.practical_explanation: Blackmailing someone by threatening to accuse them of a serious crime like murder or rape.
388.example: Threatening to file a false rape case unless paid.

overlaps.description: Putting person in fear of accusation

493.title: Cohabitation caused by a man deceitfully inducing a belief of lawful marriage
493.legal_text: Every man who by deceit causes any woman who is not lawfully married to him to believe that she is lawfully married to him and to cohabit with him...
493.punishment: Imprisonment up to 10 years and fine
493.nature:
Non-cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
493.practical_explanation: Tricking a woman into believing she is married to you to have sex.
493.example: Performing a fake wedding ceremony to live with a woman.

496.title: Marriage ceremony fraudulently gone through without lawful marriage
496.legal_text: Whoever, dishonestly or with a fraudulent intention, goes through the ceremony of being married, knowing that he is not thereby lawfully married...
496.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
496.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
496.example: Pretending to marry just to get dowry/status.

505.title: Statements conducing to public mischief
505.legal_text: Whoever makes, publishes or circulates any statement, rumor or report... with intent to cause, or which is likely to cause, any officer, soldier... to mutiny... or to cause fear or alarm to the public.
505.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years (or 5 years in place of worship)
505.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
505.practical_explanation: Spreading rumors to cause panic or mutiny.
505.example: Circulating fake news causing a riot.

507.title: Criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication
507.legal_text: Whoever commits the offence of criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication, or having taken precaution to conceal the name...
507.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years (in addition to Section 506 punishment)
507.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
507.practical_explanation: Threatening someone anonymously (e.g. unknown caller, anonymous letter).

508.title: Act caused by inducing person to believe that he will be rendered an object of the Divine displeasure
508.legal_text: Whoever voluntarily causes or attempts to cause any person to do anything which that person is not legally bound to do... by inducing... belief that he... will become an object of Divine displeasure.
508.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
508.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
508.practical_explanation: Scaring someone into doing something by claiming God will punish them.
508.example: A godman threatening a curse if a devotee doesn't donate money.

501.title: Printing or engraving matter known to be defamatory
501.legal_text: Whoever prints or engraves any matter, knowing or having good reason to believe that such matter is defamatory of any person.
501.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
501.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
501.example: Printing a magazine full of lies about someone.
